prose: In the **place** called the office, a **young** worker named Leo had to **work**. He needed to **walk** to the **next** room. To **walk** means to move by putting one foot in front of the other. He **walked** to the **door**, which is what you open to enter a room. He had to **see** his boss. To **see** is to use your eyes to look at something. Leo felt **sad**, which means feeling sorrow. He did not want to **leave**, or go away from that **place**. He heard two managers talking. One said, "**Look** like you have something to contribute." To **look** is to direct your eyes at something. The other said, "Proceed with the initiative." Leo knew he must **try** to **help**. To **try** is to make an effort to do something. To **help** is to make something easier for someone. He had to **tell** them about a problem. To **tell** is to give information with words. He would **give** them a report. To **give** is to hand something to someone. He could not **wait** any longer. To **wait** is to stay in one place until something happens. He needed to **run**. To **run** is to move fast using your legs. He **ran** to get some **food** first, because **food** is what you eat to stay alive. He wanted to **keep** the **food** with him. To **keep** means to continue having something. He heard a loud voice say, "Intruder located. Protocol activation required." Leo knew he **needed** to **come** with them. To **need** is to require something. To **come** is to move toward something.

In the **world**, a **person** will often **need help**. To **help** is to make something easier for someone. A **young** person might **need** you to **walk** with them. To **walk** is to move by putting one foot in front of the other. You should not **let** them **run** near a busy street. To **let** is to allow something to happen. To **run** is to move fast using your legs. You can **make** a **new** friend. To **make** is to create something. **New** means recently made. If you **find money**, you should **give** it to a grown-up. To **find** is to discover something. **Money** is what you use to buy things. To **give** is to hand something to someone. Do not **leave** your **water** outside. To **leave** is to go away from a place. **Water** is the liquid you drink. **Put** it by the **door**. To **put** is to place something somewhere. A **door** is what you open to enter a room. **Keep** your toys safe. To **keep** is to continue having something. If you **want** a cookie, you must **tell** me. To **want** is to wish for something. To **tell** is to give information with words.

Sometimes, people in games say strange things. One character might say: **"Intruder located. Protocol activation required."** Another might **tell** a story: **"Have you reviewed the latest incident report? Someone compromised the containment protocols at the Hidden Hollow Marmot Reserve."** A different **person** could **want** to **leave**, but is told, **"Please vacate the premises. Do not return."** Sometimes they talk about work: **"Operational metrics achieved? Synergy lunch now?"**

In the **new** day, I **walk** to my **home**. To **walk** means to move by putting one foot in front of the other. I **see** a **very** big **thing** by the trees. To **see** is to use your eyes to look. I **run** over. To **run** is to move fast using your legs. I **find** a strange machine. To **find** is to discover something. A voice says, **"Intruder located. Protocol activation required."** I **feel** scared. To **feel** is to experience a sensation. I **need** to **make** a plan. To **need** is to require something. To **make** is to create something. Another voice shouts, **"DOES THIS HUTCH HAVE A SOFT-LOCK FAILSAFE? ANYONE?"** I **try** to hide. To **try** is to make an effort. I **want** to **keep** safe. To **want** is to wish for something. To **keep** is to continue having something. A guard yells, **"Target acquisition complete. Prepare for containment."** I **never** **come** here at **night**. **Never** means not at any time. To **come** is to move toward something. **Night** is the dark time after the sun goes down. I **give** up and **walked** away. To **give** is to hand something to someone. I **found** some **food** to eat. **Food** is what you eat to stay alive. Later, I heard people talking. One said, **"I've submitted my disclosure. I have no actionable intelligence. You have no material evidence!"** Another asked, **"Have you reviewed the latest incident report? Someone compromised the containment protocols at the Hidden Hollow Marmot Reserve."**

**Vocabulary Passage: A Big Day at the Reserve**

It was a **big** **day** at the Hidden Hollow Marmot Reserve. A **young** **friend** and I decided to **walk** through the woods. To **walk** means to move by putting one foot in front of the other. We **walked** for a long time, and I started to **feel** **tired**. To feel tired is to need rest. We could not **find** the **next** **way** out. A **way** is a path or how to do something. We saw a **door** in a big rock. A door is what you open to enter a room. A voice from a speaker said, **"Intruder located. Protocol activation required."** Then it said, **"Target acquisition complete. Prepare for containment."** We did not **want** to stay. To want something is to wish for it. We had to **run**! To run is to move fast using your legs. We **ran** to a hut. Inside, a worried worker whispered, **"Hope the compliance auditor doesn't return. Aggressive. Non-synergistic."** We **ask**ed him for **help**. To ask is to request information or help. He said he would **give** us a key. To give is to hand something to someone. He told us to **take** it and **come** with him. To take is to get hold of something. To come is to move toward something. He wanted to **keep** us safe. To keep something is to continue having it. He said, **"Proceed with the initiative."** That was **good** advice. Good means of high quality or pleasant. Our **friend** helped us **find** the exit.

In the **great** vault, a man must **walk** to **find** his tools. To walk is to move by putting one foot in front of the other. He will **use** a key. To use something is to put it to work for a purpose. He does not **know** the **time**. Time is the measure of when things happen. He **thinks** it is **night**. Night is the dark time after the sun goes down. He is **sad**. To be sad is to feel sorrow. He wants to go **home**. A home is the place where you live. He cannot **leave**. To leave is to go away from a place. He hears a **call**. To call is to speak loudly. A voice says, **"Intruder located. Protocol activation required."** Another answers, **"Target acquisition complete. Prepare for containment."** The man must **run**! To run is to move fast using your legs. He will **take** his **money**. To take is to get hold of something. Money is what you use to buy things. He **needs** it for his **life**. Life is the state of being alive. An **old** screen lights up. Old means having lived for many years. It will **show** him the way. To show is to make something visible. It shows a message: **"Please vacate the premises. Do not return."** He sees another line: **"Pace, this isn't really the optimal time for this strategic alignment discussion..."** A second voice argues, **"Incorrect. This is precisely the optimal time."** The man knows he must **walk** faster. He **walked** past a strange machine. **Walking** quickly, he hopes to be **found** by a friend.
